biogHist.abstract: The Girls' Friendly Society (GFS) opened in Perth in 1914. From the 1950s, possibly earlier and for an unknown period, the Girls' Friendly Society provided emergency accommodation for female Wards of the Department if alternative suitable placement could not be found. In 2013, it remained active in Australia, known simply as GFS.
biogHist.p: The Girls' Friendly Society (GFS) came to Australia from England in 1875. The first GFS was in South Australia and from 1875 the organisation spread to all States, operating in 14 Anglican Dioceses. The GFS opened a branch in Perth in 1914 and was very active in fundraising, especially for the Parkerville Children's Home, the Perth Girls' Orphanage and Swan Homes. From the 1950s and possibly earlier, the Girls' Friendly Society provided emergency accommodation for female Wards of the Department if alternative suitable placement could not be found. In 2013, it remained active in Australia, known simply as GFS.

The GFS Lodge was started in 1917 and followed a lodge that was operated by the Anglican Diocese - St George' s Lodge. Two more lodges were established, one in Perth and another in Fremantle. GFS Lodge, also called Townsend Lodge was also used as accommodation by Curtin University in the 1990s for a couple of years. In 2013 Townsend Lodge was used as low budget accommodation and managed by Swanleigh.

descriptiveNote.p: The Girls' Friendly Society was actively involved with fundraising for the Perth Girls' Orphanage.
Girls' Friendly Society was actively involved with fundraising for Swan Homes.

archref.unittitle: The Noisy Mansions : the story of Swanleigh 1868-1971
archref.abstract: This is a digital copy of The Noisy Mansions, which is a history of the Western Australian Anglican orphanage which became Swan Homes and finally Swanleigh. The Noisy Mansions was written by A. Roy Peterkin, the long-standing Director of the Home.
archref.note: Perth Diocesan Trustees, Anglican Church of Australia.
